channel.title: Wiring my computer
channel.description:
k so i had this idea that i could possibly connect my computer to two plug sockets simultaneously, so if one is switched off the computer will stay on. it sounds simple, but would it work?
i made a diagram of the circuit i intend to make: [IMG]http://i42.tinypic.com/2yjx55z.png[/img]
if both plugs were live at the same time, would there be a surge of power or anything?

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Um, is it possible to convert to DC and then back to AC? I can understand DC>AC but I’m not sure how you would simulate the wave.

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @Brett2 Brett`
item.description:
@Brett2 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:44, topic:339833”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=436205.msg3226627#msg3226627 date=1275633830]

apparently they dont have electrical regulations on houses in the US

We do, even though I think some of them are stupid. ;D

Anyway, if you plug it into two outlets on the same circuit you will of course be all right, but the only advantage it would give you is so you could ‘move it around’ without unplugging it. Don’t know how handy that would be.

If you put a fuse anywhere on your set of plugs, the same scenario I laid out holds, it doesn’t help anything. However if you wire each individual plug so electricity could only flow one way, it should be pretty safe and do exactly what you want. I know there are electronics that do this, I’ve used them before on a 12V DC truck, they resemble resistors but were black with a gray band around the end to indicate which way the electricity could travel, I don’t remember what they are called though, and I don’t know if you could get them to handle that much power.
[/quote]Diodes? I don’t think you could do something like that with AC because current doesn’t actually flow, it just alternates.[/quote]

Buuttttt you can use 4 diodes and a capacitor to create a rectifier which would convert the AC into DC! I’m not really sure where that would get you though. And you can get diodes that handle about as much voltage as you want, i’d imagine that power companies use them somewhere along the line. My school has some giant ones that were used for 720V, I have no idea where they were from, or why the electronics teacher has them. He just does. Funny side note; this electronics teacher is named Dave Watts. I’ve always found that amusing.

Read full topic

We do, even though I think some of them are stupid. ;D

Anyway, if you plug it into two outlets on the same circuit you will of course be all right, but the only advantage it would give you is so you could ‘move it around’ without unplugging it. Don’t know how handy that would be.

If you put a fuse anywhere on your set of plugs, the same scenario I laid out holds, it doesn’t help anything. However if you wire each individual plug so electricity could only flow one way, it should be pretty safe and do exactly what you want. I know there are electronics that do this, I’ve used them before on a 12V DC truck, they resemble resistors but were black with a gray band around the end to indicate which way the electricity could travel, I don’t remember what they are called though, and I don’t know if you could get them to handle that much power.[/quote]Diodes? I don’t think you could do something like that with AC because current doesn’t actually flow, it just alternates.

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

apparently they dont have electrical regulations on houses in the US

We do, even though I think some of them are stupid. ;D

Anyway, if you plug it into two outlets on the same circuit you will of course be all right, but the only advantage it would give you is so you could ‘move it around’ without unplugging it. Don’t know how handy that would be.

If you put a fuse anywhere on your set of plugs, the same scenario I laid out holds, it doesn’t help anything. However if you wire each individual plug so electricity could only flow one way, it should be pretty safe and do exactly what you want. I know there are electronics that do this, I’ve used them before on a 12V DC truck, they resemble resistors but were black with a gray band around the end to indicate which way the electricity could travel, I don’t remember what they are called though, and I don’t know if you could get them to handle that much power.

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:38, topic:339833”]Here is what will happen if you do that.

Say you plug your computer into two different sockets on two different circuits (if they are on the same circuit, it would be the same as plugging them both into the same socket), we will call the circuits A and B.

Unless you put something in place to stop electricity from going from circuit A to B and vice-versa, you will have problems, some potentially dangerous. For example:

If something short-circuits on B, instead of the fuse blowing at the 15amps B is supposed to pull, it also can pull 15 amps from A, effectively pulling twice as many amps as the wires are rated for, potentially heating them up and catching them on fire. So as you can see, this won’t even work the way you want it to because a short on one circuit will either A) blow the fuses on both circuits, or B) catch your house on fire.

DON’T DO IT!!![/quote]
No mitb, let the idiot do it!

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @Brett2 Brett`
item.description:
@Brett2 wrote:

Putting a fuse on the cable before it goes into your computer will only save your computer from what Mopar said, the wires will still heat up. the only way to stop that would to get a thicker gauge wire, but I wouldn’t recommend that. Besides if you’re using outlets on the same fuse (circuit) in your house if one outlet is short-circuited both of them will be shut off because either the breaker will be tripped or the fuse will pop. So you’re basically plugging it into a power strip or surge protector twice lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Ooh right. So it would work fine unless it short circuited, in which case it’d burn down my house? And using two sockets on the same circuit is fine?

OOh also just had another idea. If I put a fuse on the single cable just before it enters the computer, then would this reduce the issue of cable melting?

I don’t think I’m actually going to do this now, just curious =p

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Here is what will happen if you do that.

Say you plug your computer into two different sockets on two different circuits (if they are on the same circuit, it would be the same as plugging them both into the same socket), we will call the circuits A and B.

Unless you put something in place to stop electricity from going from circuit A to B and vice-versa, you will have problems, some potentially dangerous. For example:

If something short-circuits on B, instead of the fuse blowing at the 15amps B is supposed to pull, it also can pull 15 amps from A, effectively pulling twice as many amps as the wires are rated for, potentially heating them up and catching them on fire. So as you can see, this won’t even work the way you want it to because a short on one circuit will either A) blow the fuses on both circuits, or B) catch your house on fire.

DON’T DO IT!!!

Read full topic

item.title: Wiring my computer
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:26, topic:339833”]how does switching off a socket thats plugged into a pc psu save the environment? :/[/quote]i said that my dad goes around switching stuff off, not me, so i can’t really argue his point. his reason is, allegedly, to save power. i’m not sure if he actually thinks it’s going to save any power or if he’s just being a twat, but he still does it and obviously doesn’t listen to a word i say.

one of the main reasons i got a ups was because of this, but it only lasts 30 mins so is pretty useless when i’m at school etc.

anyway can this thread please be about electricity, not family issues and inferior plug sockets? i just want an to know the physics explaining why this wont work, not a simple statement of no.

Read full topic
